# Draft:Children Born of War

----
Children Born of War (CBOW) is the term used to describe children that have one parent that was part of an army or peace keeping force and the other parent a local citizen.
It includes four different classifications: children of enemy soldiers, children of occupation soldiers, children born of child soldiers and children born of members of peacekeeping forces.
The term is relatively new and was created in order to have a more precise way to describe this group of children, who are typically othered and potentially abused both during and after war or conflict due to hatred towards the enemy. Previously, this group of children has often been called "war children", a term that is also used for children generally suffering during war and conflict and also child soldiers.
The challenges for Children Born of War are distinctly different, although these children might also belong to other categories of war children. It is also worth noting that the term includes all children with the described parentage, regardless of whether the conception was consentual or not.
The concept of Children Born of War has been defined by professor doctor Ingvill Constanze Ã˜degaard (nee Mochmann) in an article in 2006  and 2008 . These articles further development the description of the term presented in a research report by R. Charli Carpenter .
A more thorough description of the concept and the research on Children Born of War can be found on the research page of the foundation "The Children Born of War Project", a NGO working for the rights and protection of CBOW the world over.
